articles.headline: Giving to a Newborn’s College Savings Plan
articles.snippet: The process of tossing some money into a college savings account as a gift is not as easy as it could, or should, be.
articles.abstract: The process of tossing some money into a college savings account as a gift is not as easy as it could, or should, be.
articles.lead_paragraph: The best gift any of us can give to newborn babies is to point their sleep-deprived parents in the direction of a good 529 or other college savings plan and then seed the account with a little bit of money.

articles.headline: Rage by Miners Points to Shift in South Africa
articles.snippet: The unrest at South African mines has placed the spotlight on the country’s business leaders and politicians, who once led protests and are now wealthy members of the establishment.
articles.abstract: The unrest at South African mines has placed the spotlight on the country’s business leaders and politicians, who once led protests and are now wealthy members of the establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When 360,000 gold and coal miners walked off the job in South Africa in 1987, protesting the poor pay and grim working conditions of apartheid-era mines, a charismatic young man named Cyril Ramaphosa, the firebrand leader of the National Union of Mineworkers, led the charge.

articles.headline: In Louisiana, the Water Gives, and Takes Away
articles.snippet: Plaquemines Parish, the marshy peninsula of southeastern Louisiana, was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.
articles.abstract: Plaquemines Parish, the marshy peninsula of southeastern Louisiana, was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENICE, La. — The end of the earth was farther away than usual.

articles.headline: Mortgage Registry Muddles Foreclosures
articles.snippet: MERS, the Mortgage Electronic Registration System set up by banks to track mortgages, is under fire for inaccuracies that cost one Ohio homeowner dearly.
articles.abstract: MERS, the Mortgage Electronic Registration System set up by banks to track mortgages, is under fire for inaccuracies that cost one Ohio homeowner dearly.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORE good news from the housing front last week. Pending home sales rose 2.4 percent in July, to their highest level since April 2010. Mortgage delinquency rates are down: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decline of 6.3 percent at the end of June from the March quarter.

articles.headline: Inquiry on Tax Strategy Adds to Scrutiny of Finance Firms
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general is investigating whether private equity firms converted fees into investments to reduce their tax bills, raising pressure on an industry bruised by the campaign season.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general is investigating whether private equity firms converted fees into investments to reduce their tax bills, raising pressure on an industry bruised by the campaign season.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general is investigating whether some of the nation’s biggest private equity firms have abused a tax strategy in order to slice hundreds of millions of dollars from their tax bills, according to executives with direct knowledge of the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Julie Creswell and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: When the Work-Life Scales Are Unequal
articles.snippet: The pursuit of “work-life balance,” which sounds so wholesome and reasonable, can be a zero-sum game in the office.
articles.abstract: The pursuit of “work-life balance,” which sounds so wholesome and reasonable, can be a zero-sum game in the office.
articles.lead_paragraph: KELLY Azevedo used to work upward of 70 hours a week.

articles.headline: Tony Hayward Gets His Life Back
articles.snippet: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
articles.abstract: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON

articles.headline: Airstrikes Push Waves of Syrians to Jordanian Camps
articles.snippet: Since air assaults by Syria’s government picked up two weeks ago, knocking rebels in the south on their heels, refugees have been arriving at camps in Jordan at a rate of about 2,000 a night.
articles.abstract: Since air assaults by Syria’s government picked up two weeks ago, knocking rebels in the south on their heels, refugees have been arriving at camps in Jordan at a rate of about 2,000 a night.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAATARI, Jordan — The five Jamous brothers were early recruits to the Free Syrian Army, eager to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

articles.headline: The Other Power in the West Wing
articles.snippet: Valerie Jarrett, a senior White House adviser with unmatched access to the Obamas, has been a driving force in some of the most significant domestic policy decisions of the president’s first term.
articles.abstract: Valerie Jarrett, a senior White House adviser with unmatched access to the Obamas, has been a driving force in some of the most significant domestic policy decisions of the president’s first term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama was in a bind, and his chief of staff could not figure out how he had ended up there.

articles.headline: In a Tactical Test, Romney Stakes Hopes on Ohio
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s path to the White House would be severely narrowed without the 18 electoral votes from Ohio, where he continues to trail President Obama in polls.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s path to the White House would be severely narrowed without the 18 electoral votes from Ohio, where he continues to trail President Obama in polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Fresh off his nominating convention, Mitt Romney is cranking up a well-financed political machine that will now bring its full force to bear on President Obama with a hailstorm of ads and nonstop campaigning.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: U.S. Halts Training Program for Some Afghan Recruits
articles.snippet: Training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold to better screen out threats to troops, officials say.
articles.abstract: Training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold to better screen out threats to troops, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold while their American trainers conduct stricter vetting to try to root out any infiltrators or new recruits who could pose risks to the coalition troops working with them, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: In Pivotal Week for Euro Zone, a Test for the Central Bank’s Leader
articles.snippet: Some analysts say Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank’s president, might have a difficult time convincing investors that the bank will take decisive action against the euro debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Some analysts say Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank’s president, might have a difficult time convincing investors that the bank will take decisive action against the euro debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The last time Mario Draghi addressed the news media after a meeting of the European Central Bank, on Aug. 2, he disappointed investors who wanted him to crack his whip and immediately bring bond markets to heel. The markets dropped even before Mr. Draghi was done speaking.

articles.headline: U.S. Companies Brace for an Exit From the Euro by Greece
articles.snippet: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American firms are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece may soon be forced to leave the euro zone.
articles.abstract: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American firms are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece may soon be forced to leave the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American companies are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece could soon be forced to leave the euro zone.

articles.headline: Rivals Jostle Before Apple Announces New iPhone
articles.snippet: Some major tech companies are running elaborate product announcements this week, hoping to grab the news media’s undivided attention before Apple announces its new iPhone on Sept. 12.
articles.abstract: Some major tech companies are running elaborate product announcements this week, hoping to grab the news media’s undivided attention before Apple announces its new iPhone on Sept. 12.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back when Apple was an underdog, it had an easier time shrouding its product announcements in mystery and perhaps catching its competitors off guard.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Left Alone by Its Owner, Reddit Soars
articles.snippet: Reddit, built on open-source software and guided by the ethos of its community of 20 million users a month, is a classic Web start-up in which opportunity seems mixed with barely controlled anarchy.
articles.abstract: Reddit, built on open-source software and guided by the ethos of its community of 20 million users a month, is a classic Web start-up in which opportunity seems mixed with barely controlled anarchy.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are many ways to measure the traction of a social media platform: time spent, page views or unique users. But it might be useful to add one more metric: if the leader of the free world stops by to answer questions from your users, you’re probably doing O.K.

articles.headline: Twitter’s Free Speech Defender
articles.snippet: Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. As the company considers going public, he thinks it is a competitive advantage.
articles.abstract: Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. As the company considers going public, he thinks it is a competitive advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.

articles.headline: Garden & Gun Claws Its Way Back From the Brink
articles.snippet: Since losing financial support from its publisher in 2009, the Southern lifestyle magazine Garden & Gun has made an impressive recovery, adding more than 20,000 subscribers in 2011.
articles.abstract: Since losing financial support from its publisher in 2009, the Southern lifestyle magazine Garden & Gun has made an impressive recovery, adding more than 20,000 subscribers in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Among the many magazines that were battered by the recession, few survived such a precarious financial state as Garden & Gun.

articles.headline: Ticket Sales Fail to Make Hollywood’s Summer
articles.snippet: Even higher prices could not offset empty seats this summer as ticket sales at North American cinemas declined an estimated 3 percent from the period a year earlier.
articles.abstract: Even higher prices could not offset empty seats this summer as ticket sales at North American cinemas declined an estimated 3 percent from the period a year earlier.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This is one summer Hollywood would like to remake.

articles.headline: To Calm Israel, U.S. Offers Ways to Restrain Iran
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is taking steps it hopes will force Iran to reconsider almost stalemated nuclear negotiations — and forestall an Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is taking steps it hopes will force Iran to reconsider almost stalemated nuclear negotiations — and forestall an Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Israel openly debating whether to strike at Iran’s nuclear facilities in the coming months, the Obama administration is moving ahead with a range of steps short of war that it hopes will forestall an Israeli attack, while forcing the Iranians to take more seriously negotiations that are all but stalemated.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Hitting Pause in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits was the first tap on the brakes for one of the most controversial programs in the Afghan security plan.
articles.abstract: A decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits was the first tap on the brakes for one of the most controversial programs in the Afghan security plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American commander’s decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits for at least a month was the first tap on the brakes for what has been a headlong drive to fill out a police force. From the very beginning, the program has been one of the most controversial in the Afghan security plan.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: The Competitor in Chief
articles.snippet: President Obama has earned a reputation as a perpetually aspiring overachiever, striving to perfect his skills even in mundane pursuits like doodling.
articles.abstract: President Obama has earned a reputation as a perpetually aspiring overachiever, striving to perfect his skills even in mundane pursuits like doodling.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Election Day approaches, President Obama is sharing a few important things about himself. He has mentioned more than once in recent weeks that he cooks “a really mean chili.” He has impressive musical pitch, he told an Iowa audience. He is “a surprisingly good pool player,” he informed an interviewer — not to mention (though he does) a doodler of unusual skill.
